abstract.p: The quality of surface is one of the significant parameters which affects the life and functionality of any product. Many products require nano-level surface finish as their functional indispensability. Those processes having flexible finishing tool can be employed for such type of components. These finishing processes can be classified into two categories: with and without magnetic field assistance. The former includes magnetic abrasive finishing, magnetorheological finishing, and allied processes, and the latter includes abrasive flow finishing. This article reports the critical review of mainly three processes: abrasive flow finishing, magnetorheological finishing, and magnetorheological abrasive flow finishing. In this article, the issues that need attention of the researchers have been categorically mentioned. This article provides a comprehensive literature review of magnetorheological finishing process in terms of rheological characterization of magnetorheological fluid, experimental investigation, theoretical analysis, and applications. This article deals with various advancements in abrasive flow finishing and hybrid processes. The developments in magnetorheological abrasive flow finishing and its allied processes have been discussed in detail. By suitable modification of magnetorheological abrasive flow finishing process, it can achieve surface finish up to nano-meter on different materials such as brass, aluminium, stainless steel, and silicon-nitride.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: In the era of nanotechnology, high precision finishing methods are of utmost importance, and they are the need of present day manufacturing industries. There are noteworthy developments in high technology industries such as electronics, automobile, medical, and aviation, where the focus is to increase precision of the products at micro-/nano-scale to perform certain functions. Many products exist in the market where highest level of surface finish is necessary to increase their life and performance. Some of them are silicon in IC industries, micro-channels in micro-fluidics, optics and free-form surfaces in medical science, and moving assembly such as piston-cylinder and bearings in automobile. The traditional finishing processes alone are incapable of producing the required surface characteristics to meet the demand of nanotechnology. Many components require high level of surface finish to reduce fluid flow resistance, friction, and optical losses. Fatigue strength of a component is also affected by surface conditions. Usually, a surface finish improvement operation is required during or after fabrication of a part. Abrasive-based traditional finishing processes, such as grinding, honing, and lapping, are not capable of producing ultrafine surface on three-dimensional (3D) complex-shaped components and very hard material components due to the abrasives in the bonded form and high specific cutting energy requirement. Therefore, loose abrasive finishing processes, such as chemo-mechanical polishing/planarization, abrasive flow finishing (AFF), and magnetic field-assisted finishing processes, are preferable over the traditional finishing processes. However, many finishing processes, such as lapping, chemo-mechanical polishing, and AFF, are not deterministic in nature because the abrading forces acting on the workpiece are not externally controllable by other means such as magnetic field.

In this article, AFF, magnetorheological finishing (MRF), and magnetorheological abrasive flow finishing (MRAFF) processes have been reviewed. The performance of the first one cannot be externally controlled whereas the performance of the other two can be controlled in-process by changing the magnetic field intensity. The beauty of all these processes is that they can finish complex-shaped 3D components apart from finishing of inaccessible areas and miniature features.

sec.title: 2 MAGNETORHEOLOGICAL FINISHING
sec.p:
In the absence of magnetic field, the MR fluid behaves as a Newtonian viscous fluid. The magnetic field stiffens the MRP fluid ribbon depending upon the field strength and it behaves like a visco-plastic fluid. Magnetic field and CIPs are necessary to produce magnetorheological (MR) effect while NMAPs are responsible for material removal in MRF process. Magnetic particles are uniformly dispersed when there is no magnetic field, as shown in Fig. 1(a). On the application of magnetic field, CIPs are attracted towards the magnet and create a chain-like structure along the lines of the magnetic field (Fig. 1(b)). When NMAPs are added in the MRP fluid, they are gripped by the magnetic particles chains, as shown in Fig. 1(c). Fig. 1
Distribution of magnetic particles (a) without magnetic field, (b) with magnetic field, and (c) NMAPs (deliberately chosen of much bigger size for this photograph) embedded in the magnetic particles chains

In the MRF process (Fig. 2(a)), a convex, flat, or concave workpiece is positioned below a rotating carrier wheel. A ribbon is formed on the carrier wheel by the MRP fluid delivered by the nozzle. Two MRP fluid pumps (peristaltic or centrifugal) are used for delivery and suction of MR fluid from the carrier wheel. By applying magnetic field using an electromagnet or a permanent magnet, the stiffened MR fluid forms a finishing spot at the ribbon–workpiece interface during finishing. A fluid conditioning and storage system is used to control MRP fluid temperature, to prevent sedimentation of solids through stirring of MRP fluid, and to monitor/add water which is lost by evaporation during finishing operation. Material removal takes place due to the interaction between the stiffened MR fluid and workpiece when the MR fluid ribbon is dragged into the converging gap (finishing zone) by rotating carrier wheel. Figure 2(b) shows a magnified view of mechanics of material removal during MRF process, showing normal and tangential forces responsible for penetration and shearing of peaks during finishing, respectively. Fig. 2
(a) Schematic of MR fluid-based finishing process and (b) magnified view of finishing zone

Majority of the work reported in the literature is experimental in nature in which different configurations of the machine setup are developed depending on the size and the shape of the workpiece to be finished, whereas some researchers have studied this process theoretically in which the models are developed for evaluating material removal and forces acting on the workpiece surface. This article reviews these aspects of the MRF process along with rheological characterization of MRP fluid.

sec.title: 2.1 Rheological characterization of MR fluid for MRF process
sec.p: Rheological characterization includes the study of yield stress, viscosity, and temperature of MR fluid with or without the application of magnetic field. Majority of the reported work related to the study of rheological properties of MR fluid uses MR fluid where no NMAPs are added to it. Such MR fluid is used in brakes, clutches, dampers, etc. Only a few researchers have reported the rheological characterization of MR fluid with NMAPs, as discussed in the following sections.

It is found that the magnetic susceptibility of MR fluid increases with the increase in magnetic particle size as well as concentration [
6
]. Structural changes, including particles organization such as translation, aggregation, and chaining, occurring in the MR fluid during use lead to susceptibility drift and may affect fluid performance. Nevertheless, the reported results are only useful to study the size effect of CIPs in the case of MRF process. Sidpara et al. [
7
] investigated the effect of CIPs concentration, NMAPs concentration, magnetic field, and water concentration on yield stress and viscosity of MRP fluid. Magnetic field is found as the most significant factor which affects both yield stress and viscosity. The MR fluid rheological curves are fitted with well-known visco-plastic fluids models such as Herschel–Bulkley, Bingham Plastic, and Casson fluid. It is found that Herschel–Bulkley model fits better with the experimental results compared to Bingham Plastic and Casson fluid models, as shown in Fig. 3. Study of other parameters, such as temperature, size of CIPs, as well as NMAPs, is required as an extension of the reported work.
Fig. 3
Fitting of MR fluid rheology curves by visco-plastic fluid models

Sidpara and Jain [ 8 ] studied the effect of MRP fluid composition on finishing single-crystal silicon. An experimental study is conducted with oil- and water-based MR fluids with the addition of NMAPs: aluminium oxide (Al2O3) and cerium oxide (CeO2). It is found that MRP fluid having CeO2 and water is more effective for nano-finishing of silicon. Figure 4 shows atomic force microscope images of unfinished and finished silicon surfaces having 10 nm surface roughness obtained by MRF process with CeO2 and water-based MR fluid. The results of rheological study show that yield stress of oil-based MRP fluid is lower than the water-based one. It is also found that the yield stress and viscosity of MRP fluid decrease with its use due to contamination with the removed material in the form of micro-/nano-chips. Therefore, MRP fluid should be periodically conditioned/changed during finishing operation. Fig. 4
AFM image of (a) unfinished (R a = 1280 nm) and (b) finished (R a = 10 nm) silicon workpiece

Based on the above literature review, it is concluded that hardly any report is available with emphasis on improving the stability of MRP fluid used in MRF process. Reuse and storage of MRP fluid are very difficult because its rheological properties decay (especially in the case of water-based MRP fluid) when it is stored for a longtime. Therefore, long-term stability of MRP fluid is one of the prime issues which needs to be addressed.

sec.title: 2.2 Experimental investigations
2.2.1 Forces in MRF
sec.p:
Sidpara and Jain [ 29 ] investigated the effect of CIPs concentration, NMAPs concentration, carrier wheel speed, and working gap on the normal force (F n) and tangential force (F t). The normal and tangential forces increase with an increase in NMAPs concentration up to an optimum level beyond which they start decreasing (Fig. 5). The maximum contribution to the forces acting on the workpiece surface is made by working gap followed by CIPs concentration whereas the least contribution is noticed in the case of wheel speed. It indicates that the MRF process performance is dominated by the magnetic field and magnetic particles concentration compared to other parameters. Fig. 5
Effect of NMAPs concentration on the measured forces (F n and F t) (CIPs = 40%, wheel speed = 300 r/min, and working gap = 1 mm)

sec.title: 2.4 Applications
3 ABRASIVE FLOW FINISHING
sec.p:
In AFF process, polymer-based visco-elastic abrasive medium is extruded back and forth between two vertically opposite cylinders (Fig. 9). This medium finishes the workpiece surface selectively while extruding through the passage formed by the workpiece and tooling [ 37 ]. Because of the flow through the restricted narrow passage in the workpiece region, the polymer chains hold abrasive particles (APs) flexibly and orient themselves in the direction of applied extrusion pressure. Thus, the medium acts as a multipoint flexible cutting tool. Extrusion pressure, number of cycles, workpiece initial surface roughness, and medium viscosity are some of the variable parameters that have an impact on the achievable final surface roughness. When appropriate extrusion pressure is applied on the visco-elastic medium, it moves along the direction of applied pressure with axial velocity (V a) and axial force (F a). It exerts radial force (F r) due to elastic component of the medium. Radial force (F r) helps the APs to indent in the workpiece surface and axial force (F a) removes the material in the form of micro-chips (Fig. 9(b) and (c)). Fig. 9
(a) Schematic of AFF setup, (b) magnified view showing interaction between APs and workpiece, and (c) further magnified view to show APs and μ-chip

AFF system consists of three basic elements: machine, tooling, and medium. Machine consists of hydraulic system and medium cylinders which are supported in line by supporting frame. The hydraulic system is a positive displacement system, which forces the medium through the tooling at a selected pressure and flowrate. Tooling is one of the major elements of the AFF system. Major functions of the tooling are to direct the flow of medium and to precisely control the area to be finished [ 38 , 39 ].

The medium is an important element of AFF process as it is a primary flexible cutting tool of the process, and it is also called as self-deformable stone. The medium should possess three basic properties, namely, good flow ability, self-deformability, and abrading ability to finish the given surface to nano-scale. The medium should also possess enough degree of cohesion and tenacity to drag the APs along with it through various passages. The medium composition and its rheological properties are important to understand the role of medium in the mechanism of material removal [ 40 , 41 ].

sec.title: 3.1 Classification of AFF machine
sec.p:
AFF machines are classified into four types: one-way AFF, two-way AFF, orbital AFF, and micro-AFF. One-way AFF process extrudes the medium unidirectionally. During extrusion of the medium, the APs shear the peaks of the workpiece surface and reduce its Ra value. After extrusion, the medium comes out of the workpiece and it is recirculated (Fig. 10(a)). This process is good for components with complex internal shapes where forward flow of the medium is easy but not the reverse. Figure 10(b) shows a sectional view of orbital AFF of a solid, complex-shaped component having no through passage. In this case, the medium is flowing across the gap between the tool and the workpiece, and the normal force is applied by pressing the tool downward. Study related to force analysis, medium thermal properties, and their effects on the process performance has not been reported in literature [ 42 ]. Fig. 10
Sectional schematic diagram of (a) one-way AFF process and (b) orbital AFF process

sec.title: 3.2 Mechanism of material removal and forces in AFF process
sec.p: In AFF process, material removal is purely carried out by mechanical abrasion. Finishing forces at the workpiece surface are low, and as a result, the workpiece surface remains stress-free or subjected to low compressive residual stress. During the AFF process, APs penetrate the workpiece surface due to radial force (F r). The axial force (F a) tries to push the indented APs in the axial direction to remove the material in the form of μ-chips (Fig. 9(c)). During the process, mechanism of material removal follows one of the three conditions which are discussed as follows.

If Fa > Freq , (Fig. 11(a)), then the material is removed in the form of μ-chip, however under certain circumstances, ploughing may take place. If Fa < Freq then there is no material removal and only indentation occurs on the workpiece surface (Fig. 11(b)). The AP may rotate and reduce the depth of penetration till it satisfies the condition of Fig. 11(a) and then removes the material. If Fa=F″ req , then the material removal is just to start (Fig. 11(c)).

The ΔR a non-linearly varies with the increase in extrusion pressure [ 37 ]. During the finishing of metal matrix composite (MMC) at low pressure, ΔR a is low. As extrusion pressure increases, ΔR a also increases. Increase in extrusion pressure leads to increase in Fa and Fr, resulting in higher ΔRa. Increase in F r increases projected area of penetration (AP), hence ΔR a increases.

At low processing oil content, ΔR a is low as the medium is stiff and behaves close to a grinding wheel. As processing oil content increases, ΔR a gradually increases due to better flowability, self-deformability, and flexible abrading ability. At about 10 per cent processing oil content, an optimum is observed in the three different types of MMCs considered [ 37 ]. As the number of cycles increases, the total number of APs participating in finishing process increases; hence, final R a value decreases (Fig. 12). Fig. 12
Variation of surface finish on Al alloy/SiC MMC (10%) with number of cycles (abrasive mesh size = 220, extrusion pressure = 6 MPa, and plasticizer wt% = 10%)

sec.title: 3.3 Recent developments in AFF Process
sec.p: Though the AFF process has many merits, it also has limitations, such as low FR (or low productivity), and incapable of correcting the minor form geometries. The medium’s finishing capabilities decline because the medium’s rheological properties decay during AFF process which results in lower FR. Many researchers have been working to improve FR, surface integrity, and compressive residual stresses produced on the finished workpiece surface. Some of the findings have been discussed in the following sections.

sec.title: 3.3.1 Magnetic AFF and electrochemically assisted abrasive flow machining
3.3.2 Obstruction-assisted AFF
sec.p: The centrifugal force-assisted AFF process uses one of the different shapes (triangular, spline, square, and rectangular) of centrifugal force generating tiny rod which is placed at the centre of the medium slug in the workpiece finishing region. The rotating rod strikes the APs that come in contact with it, and due to the centrifugal force, it moves the APs towards the workpiece. This process is claimed to increase the finishing rate by 70–80 per cent [ 49 , 50 ] but holds good only for low viscosity medium. Further, centrifugal force generating rod strikes the APs at the centre of the high-viscosity medium slug, so the probability of giving motion to the active APs is low.

sec.title: 3.3.3 Rotational AFF
sec.p:
In rotational-abrasive flow finishing (R-AFF) process, the workpiece fixture is externally rotated by a variable frequency drive. Due to the workpiece rotation and medium reciprocation, the active APs interact with the workpiece in a helical path (Fig. 13(a)). The number of peaks of workpiece surface sheared by the active APs per unit time increases in R-AFF compared to AFF process; hence, FR and MRR increase [ 51 , 52 ]. Rotation of the workpiece additionally imparts tangential force (F t) and tangential velocity (V t) along with axial force (F a), radial force (F r), and axial velocity (V a) in AFF process (Fig. 13(b) and (c)). sec.title: 3.4 Process modelling and optimization
3.5 Monitoring of AFF process
3.6 Thermal aspects
sec.p: From the above discussion of AFF process, it is concluded that the viscosity of polishing medium is the main process parameter in AFF process, which is least controllable during finishing. Hence, controlling of finishing forces by any external means is difficult in AFF process. Also, the preparation of homogeneous mixture of APs and plasticizer in visco-elastic polymeric medium is cumbersome. Preparation of different viscosity medium always needs a new polymer base medium of comparable viscosity.

sec.title: 4 MRAFF AND ROTATIONAL-MRAFF
sec.p: From the above discussion of AFF process, it is concluded that AFF is not a deterministic process because the forces acting on the workpiece cannot be controlled in-process unless medium composition and/or finishing conditions are changed online. On the other hand, in MRF process, the forces can be externally controlled but the complex shapes and very hard workpieces cannot be finished due to setup configuration and medium composition.

sec.title: 4.1 Working principle of MRAFF and parametric analysis
sec.p:
In MRAFF process, a magnetically stiffened slug of MRP fluid is extruded back and forth through the passage formed by the workpiece and fixture [ 69 ]. The finishing mechanism of MRAFF process is shown in Fig. 14. Magnetic field is selectively applied across the workpiece surface only where the abrasion is needed keeping other areas unaffected. Inside the polishing medium, the NMAPs are held by the CIP chains and they shear peaks from the workpiece surface. Fig. 14
Mechanism of MRAFF process

sec.title: 4.2 Development of R-MRAFF process
sec.p: From the above literature survey, it is concluded that the above-mentioned processes need improvement to make them suitable for uniform and faster (or higher FR) polishing of complex geometrical shapes of the workpieces. To achieve this, the researchers have modified the existing MRAFF setup and optimized the polishing conditions as discussed in the following sections.

In R-MRAFF process, other than the reciprocating motion, the polishing medium is rotated around the axis of the cylinder by imparting a rotational motion to the permanent magnets surrounding the workpiece fixture. By superimposing these two motions, a higher relative velocity and higher FR are achieved. It also produces a smoother mirror finished surface. To rotate the permanent magnets, a cylindrical fixture is designed having four slots at its periphery, 90o apart from each other to hold the magnets. This fixture is rotated by a motor having a control device. Flat workpieces are mounted at the internal surface of the cylindrical workpiece fixture having slots or cylindrical workpieces which can be directly mounted.

Under the magnetic field, the dispersed iron particles form a magnetic cluster along the magnetic lines of force and the NMAPs gather where the magnetic field is weak (Fig. 15(a)). A relative motion takes place between the NMAPs and the workpiece surface when the magnetic poles rotate. As a result, the material is removed from the workpiece surface in the form of micro-/nano-chips which lead to nano-finishing of the workpiece surface. Figure 15(b) shows the distribution (simulated by Ansoft Maxwell®) of magnetic flux density around the cylindrical fixture for non-magnetic stainless steel workpiece [ 80 ]. Fig. 15

Axial force (F a) is responsible for shearing the material whereas radial force (F r) helps the NMAP in indenting the workpiece surface (Fig. 16(b)). The forces F a and F r are proportional to the hydraulic extrusion pressure (P) and medium viscosity (F r = k P), where k is a constant of proportionality and it can be evaluated from experimental results. The forces Fa and Fr can also be calculated by simulating MRP fluid inside workpiece. Due to the rotational motion of the magnetic field, a centrifugal force (Fcen = mrω2) acts on the NMAPs which helps them in indenting the workpiece surface. It has been reported that the viscosity of MRP-fluid changes after continuous use [ 69 , 79 ]. Also, the temperature rise due to the friction and deformation of workpiece material has been observed which affects the performance of R-MRAFF. A study can be carried out to quantify and understand the changes in rheological properties of MRP-fluid, and to evolve the method to enhance the MRP-fluid’s useful life before its replacement. Further improvements in the finishing setup are required to make it useful for finishing magnetic material.

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS AND OUTLOOK
sec.p: The state-of-the-art review of MRF, AFF, and MRAFF nano-finishing techniques is presented in this article. Following conclusions can be drawn from the presented discussion.

The MRF is an effective finishing process for optical materials with a variety of shapes such as flat, spherical, aspherical, concave, and convex. It is successfully used for finishing micro as well as macro components. Surface roughness up to nanometre level is achieved without subsurface damage. Rheological characterization of MRP fluid is an important aspect to be studied for optimum selection of the constituents of MRP fluid, which controls the quality of the finished surface. Further, the stability of MRP fluid is a major concern in MRF and MRAFF processes, which needs to be investigated. It can be improved by inclusion of different types of surfactants.

AFM is capable of meeting the diverse finishing requirements of different industries, specially finishing of complex shapes for low R a value and tight tolerances. Various models are available to correlate theoretical results with experimental results. However, the major disadvantage of this process is low FR. Continuous efforts are being made by different researchers to increase FR, improve surface texture, and to enhance MRR. Enhanced performance of the AFF process is achieved by rotating the workpiece itself (i.e. R-AFF process).

R-MRAFF process has been developed as a new deterministic nano-finishing process. It has also been concluded that this process possesses the ability to correct roundness error of hard cylindrical stainless steel tubes. This process is still under developmental stage, and it can be further improved after overcoming its existing limitations.

In R-MRAFF process, magnetic field in the finishing zone cannot be varied due to the use of permanent magnets to generate rotating magnetic field. The use of electromagnet for the same (by energizing different poles alternately) will give flexibility to vary magnetic field to polish the workpieces with varied hardness. The capabilities of R-MRAFF process can be extended to polish complex geometrical shapes by suitable design of fixture and electromagnet poles. Further, 3D CFD simulation of MRP fluid in the finishing zone and simulation of surface roughness will help to automate R-MRAFF process for better finishing performance.
